name: Música criolla peruana
description: Combination of African, Spanish, and Andean influences that originated after the time of the arrival of Spanish colonists and African slaves to Peru.

children.name: Festejo
children.description: Happy and danceable Afro-Peruvian rhythm originating in the 17th century.

children.name: Landó
children.description: 16th-century Afro-Peruvian dance and music style, played primarily on the cajón and the creole guitar in a 12/8 rhythm.

children.name: Marinera
children.description: Component of the coastal dance of the same name, often considered the national dance of Peru.

children.name: Polka peruana
children.description: Peruvian adaptation of European Polka, blending Afro-Peruvian rhythms and criollo melodies.

children.name: Tondero
children.description: Backing to the fast-paced dance that originated in northern Peru in the region of Piura of the same name; bands consist of a singer, a small chorus, two guitarists, along with the cajón and sometimes a spoon player.

children.name: Vals criollo
children.description: Originally characterized by its 3/4 time, heavy reliance on strongly plucked phrase on upper strings, and its guitar solo; often accompanied by a duet or a solo singer, normally singing about patriotic themes or social dilemmas.
